MOORE'S WHARF.

are W. II. Blackwell. Thos. W. Farns- worth, the nrst Arctic Chief. Ernest F. Miller and hls brother. August II. Miller, Major Strickland. of the Northwest mount cd police, and c. 0. Rinearson. They wore the original suggestors Of the movement, and at the first meeting they added to their numbers Dr. A. II. Bryant. the real estate dealer: pr. Mahlon F. Hall, Charles E. Moody. sbanker; Ernest Peck, lawyer Harrie n. Thaeher. who was the hrst Camp Recorder; James A. Kettles. W. A. Miller and Captain E. w. Johnston. or these there are now resident In Skagway and as active members of the organization. as they were at its inception. the Miller Brothers. who were the first Arctic guides over the new ly blazed trail. W. II. Blackwell and James \. Kettles. the first Trail Blazer elected by the order. The credit for the title Of Arctic Brotherhood Is due to Major Striek- land. The Skagway Camp has long been a parent and Is really the Grand Camp or the order. although not yet formally or ganized as such. lt has already establish cd prosperous camps at Bennett, Tagish. Atlin. Dawson. Circle City and Juneau Of the membership Of these camps there Is no recent record at hand. but it can b. safely estimated that its rosters would place the total number of members of the order at from one thousand to fifteen hundred. And all this has been accom- plished since March last. The camps at Bennett, Tagish and Atlin were personally established by the first Arctic Chief. Thom- as W. Farnsworth.

 IIs MUSEUM FEATURES.

 The Brotherhood's building at this port is two stories high and measures thirty feet by ninety. Of this the lodge room takes up twenty-nine and a half feet by sixty. the full two stories in height. Then there Is the wide entrance hall and the spacious reception and reading room be- fore referred to, and three dressing rooms. Above these Is a wide balcony for the or chestra, composed of members, which dis courses sweet music throughout the work of the ritual and emphasizes its solemnlty or gives the signal for seemly mirth. A quartette of male voices also occupies the balcony during the lodge meetings. Back of this balcony and fronting on Broad way Ia A large room intended for billiards and a sleeping apartment Tor the mouse steward. The whole building is completely ! furnished in excellent taste. and Is just beg,nning to receive those interesting and home-like touches which could only have been given by personal gifts to it of Alaska relies, Indian curios. mineralogieal speel- mems. furs. art work iu gnarled branches of trees. pictures and books and SO on.

 This handsome club house has un- loubtedly been an important factor In the rapid growth of the order. Members trav- cling to the interior And in it home or comfort where they can spend their hours of waiting in reading. writing. playing games, greeting old acQuaintances anu forming new ones. It Is the place of all places. before its glowing open hfeplace. To sWap bad luck stories" Co recount the hardships gone through before the enjoy ment of such luxury was reached. On the visitors book of the club there are all ready many pages of names. and the writ CTS og every one Of these autographs VIII heartily join with the Daily Alaskan In

 wis ing the Brotherhood "A Happy New Year"

opened up the college In temporary quar- ters at the corner of Eighth and Main Streets. Now some fifty students are ad- yanclng rapidly and under as good chances as they could in any school in the United States.

 Mrs. E. s. V. McComb, the preceptress of the primary department, is an accom- pllshed lady. and Is graduate of Miehi- gan University.

 Mrs. l.. Gordon. wife of the president, has also begun a Kindergarten class in con nectlon with the collegiate school. Mrs. Gordon graduated at Piedmont College, Cumming. Ca. the first school In the United States that Dr. Gordon presided over.

 Parents now have no excuse 10 send their children below. Higher education has got It's start in Alaska and the magnificent na- tive granite building now nearly com pleted will be the pride of Skagway and Alaska. IL will lead to other high schools at Juneau. Dawson and other points. anu skagway College will be the graduating centre.

During the first year of skagway's his- tory nearly every man who remained the major portion of that time had reaped a success at least sufficiently large to justi- fy him In sending for his family and mak- Ing this his permanent home. Homes in- numerable sprung up everywhere, in the busy city and in It's quiet suburbs. and builders, carpenters, house painters and paper hangers were soon reaplng a rich harvest. But they are not sufficient in themselves to make home. After the house Is completed it needs furniture to make it a home. And SO great was the de- mand for furniture that E. k. Peoples felt Justified in starting a manufactory to meet lt. That his venture has proven a success Is substantially shown by the fact that his business buildings now occupy such a large piece of ground and that he Is again considering the adyisabllty of enlarging

 The salesrooms and sample rooms are 5Ox5O feet, and the manufacturing depart ment occupies two floors of a building ad- joining of 75x25 feet. In this latter de- partment ten workmer are employed. who turn out all kinds Of upholstery and wood work. from the latef styles of drawing room luxury to the md'o necessary kitchen | table What should make Skagway proud Of | this establishment is not the fact that | lt has added another dnner bucket brigade | to her labor army 80 rpich as that lt Is the | arst Alaskan enterprA to engage in the

 manufacture Of one oiher greates. prod

 Iets,, that of her fofsts The timber wealth of the district 50 immehsc as to

 be entirely beyond c1;ulation. and Con

 gross a long time agopassed resolution

 that none of this timbr should be export.

 cd cut of Alaska. IL sbuld have added an

 other section to this slct giving bonus

 10 those who manufltured the product

 and 80 protect those Tho engaged in this

 new enterprise In thisew country against ,he competition of thduge concerns In the States whose machinl flood the market with the cheap furnitlb that makes homes tawdry.

 Mir. Peoples did notTalt for this protcc- tion-probably never bought Of it-anl certainly has no needo fear such compe- titlon. For folding bet bookcases, tables, chairs and so on, oithe less expensive kind. he Is now uslniAlaska spruce. He finds some of 1t of a Iperior quality, and with good workmen tns out an excellent

 article that Is a cred to the first home

 manufacture Of this mense home prod

 uct.

 When the dlscussldof Alaskan affairs comes up before Congss this session, and some one asks: WI are we going to do with our vast veal of Alaska timber; how are we to get arhing out of 1t un- less permission Is graRd to ship 1t out Of

 Alaska?" the answerllll be: Ask Peo-

 ples. of Skagway."
FURNITURE MAKER.

W " W V V V @ NE of the mos, Ha,tering incidents " of the reception given to the Amer iean members of the Joint High Com mission and United States Senators last summer. m the large pavilion erected by the Chamber of Commerce for the. fur- pose, Va. their expressions of surprise at the fashionable evening toilettes of the Sksgway women present. What is more pleasing is the fact that the com bhmeut came from women of the leading society of the United States, the wives and friends of the distinguished visitors. For il Is true that man Is an unreliable critic in such m tters, and although the softer sex dress and array themselves in all the modest pride that Art invents her beauty to improve" for the express purpose of pleasing aud attracting the sterne, sex, yet the latter sees only the general effects, and never troubles him- self as to how they are produced.

 The compliment was ss well-deserved as il was Asttering. With the prosperity of the first wiuler m mind, the meu who had Toughed il iu bachelor dirt and dis order sent for their wives and families; homes were built for them and other families followed. Prosperity eontinu- iug, the wives and grown daughters be- gan to wear it's outward ant visible signs. Where "any old thing" seemed to be good enough in the beginning tue femi- mine mind began to ponder upon and desire the latest fashionable fads and faueies. Then came, according to the natural laws of supply and demand, the firm of ]. $. Graham, which started hist on Fourth avenue but some time later had to seek larger quarters and IS now well-established in the Kelly block. This hrm Is the only one in the city that devotes itself entirely 10 what is called "ladies' furnishings" but it also carries a large stock, constantly renewed, Of tue latest fashions in cloaks aud taller made suits and hats. That our women appre ciatr this and are able to keep themselves well in tue van of fashions rapid march, is shown by the fact that Chicago poet some months ago tuned his Tyre to tue tune of "rhe Grey Goose Qniil." The ladies of Skagway had been wearing the grey goose quill iu their hats for weeks before that poem appeared.

When the steamefCity of Seattle" started on her fast ts from this port direct to the Sound, le boat found no favor with the hotel bprietors. in fact. they complained that } took away their guests too quickly. Bubw they look upon the fleet steamer. altlgh she only stays a few hours in port. a sort of public benefactor. for she made such a rep- utation for comfort aiqulck passage that people from the inter will wait here for "City of Seattle" h In fact, won the first place in steam9opularity. and her passenger list on dy trip down must have made glad thaarts of her Seattle owners. In one mot of the past season she carried from hdbOO passengers. Her record trip from h to Seattle was 70 hours and her rect for the round trip six days and threehrs.

The corner bakery and eating house be- came n restaurant of the premier class with plate glass windows and Interior ht- tings and decorations such as are only met win in the Delmonicos of the larger cities But he had scarcely made his new restaur- an, and bakery the full one hundred feet. Inc depth of his lot. than other parties sought to lease 1t. and a price was offered mat no business man in Skagway could have refused Then Mir. Ronkendorf built himself another large restaurant, In many was superior and more stylish than his first endeavor. This is on Sixth Avenue al- so. and 1t Is in every way credit 10 the cItv It is stlll called by It's old name, the German Bakery. for there is a bakery ad- iunct where anything from maccaroon to s bride cake can be made at short order. and as a caterer Mir. Ronkendorf Is equal to anything from q cold lunch to a sena- torlal banquet

 he Brothernood has grown evef niore than SAagway itself lt only started last spring. with about a dozen charter mem brrs, yet lts roster today carries near,y 5v0 members with a number Of limitations at every weekly meeting; therefore it ia bound to be tle most powerful organiza- ,.ou ln Alaska. It's membership includes lau Governor and the Judge of the United States ulsulct Court and other Alaskan o..elaIs. omcers of the United states army ant navy. many of the best known klon- diaers. the leading lawyers. doctors anu u., rc.lu.s Og sSagway. majors. inspectors auI trIyatys of the Canadian police ana .taer British born. For the order Is en- t...ly uou- political. and whatever the A--er.cau or the Canadian may individ- u-4y ,ninA of tle Alasaa boundary Ques t.a. ae cannot faIl Co notice tn the lodge .oo.- ,ac Stars aud St.ipes and the Union Ja-A .utN.ned. With the motto connect i-s tAem. No Boundary Llno Here"

 BEACY OF Is RITUAL.

 Nc, oa.y ln mere membership has the or Ear.z-..-I SO rapidly grown. but tho char a.--r of Q. lIs gradually changed as mort men ot s.gl attlinments joined and tooA an .r-,r.s. .a its work. It was. for In stance. w. e1 ssA. ted. ittle. anything. a ore -aa. cu association for mere amuse u-Ls. >g.a then. however. men of taclg lt'ui minds have been more promi- utlt iu .ts cllnssls. men too. who wore hiya up .a ots1s secret orde.s. and under the summation of this Influence the ritual has sroVa fr,n its somewhat uncertain carys1lis Co one as beautiful in lts teach ings ss the work of any secret order. with DO Wor-s ss!d or things done In "a inltl- Ua.ory cerrmon.-s that are without their NeigAt Of thoaght'ul significance. It was that characteristic that led a gentleman Go refua.k after his initiation "I Ike thii bolt than any of the orders Co whlch beloLg. lt is so thoroughly Alaskan la all its work ani lu all its teachings. and therefore Of such service and bereat to those of tho country of whose manhood it Ia 10 stiiking an example"

 The order was fortunate In lts second selection ot an Arctic Chiet Co have in Major J. T. Hayue one who was not only an Ideal presiding officer.- but one who had held high positions in the Knights ot Pyth- iaA At the election Of officers last Soyem Der. the Brotherhood was equally fortu- nate iu les choice. Dr. [. II. Moore being q most enthusiastic Mason. He has been earnest In carrying on the work Of Major Haync. and In his devotion to the perfsc- tion of the ritual and the improvement oi the order Co point tn keeping with it' prospective greatness.

 But this must not be taken literally as meaning that with the advent of Major Hayne as Arctic Chief the reformation Of the ritual begun. It was tn evidence at every session Of the Brotherhood from its nrst. and thls gradual but continual deyel- opment of a central Idea is but another demonstration Of the high mental calibre s.N Hh hs. hR In kl n it tuolr home and to build up their for tunes On an average. perhaps. ten have been Initiated st each weekly scssion. anu Of them there was one or more who saw clearly the great future which tho orier might develop Into under proper ggldanee, ana they came Co the fore with suggestions born Of their cosmopolitan experience and their mental capacity.

 THOSE WHO BLAZED THE TRAIL.

 It would not be proper and. Ia fact. it would be invidlous to mention any of these unless one could mention all. and to mention ail Is impossible. for the req son that many of them believe their ef- foI ts for the good of the order. like the charity it dispenses. should be a sacred matter of personal satisfaction. of which publicity would brush the dew of modest graciousness and brotherly generosity.

 But it Is fitting In an article of thlS kind. a brief history of powerful organI- ration which came Into existence humbly and has fought it way up to It's present high position since the Issue of our last New Years edition. that some honor should be paid 10 its founders. tho men who blazed the trail. and. In great measure. spent their own time and money in doing lt.

One of the first of the better class Of restaurants established in the now city Of skagway was that of Fred Ronkendori. who came here with not only lot Of cx- perienee but some hard cash In addition to go Into business. Of an energetic and genial temperament that readily makes Of business aeQuaintances personal friends

 and with full knowledge of what he was attempting and how to go about 1t. a man in any line of business could hardly fall of success. especially In new country. Mir. Ronkendorf aid not fail by any means. His German Bakery was very soon a pop ular eating house and as the city grew and put on trills. so did Fred's establishment.

THE GERMAN BAKERY AND ITS

 PROPRIETOR.

ue Of the greatest luNestments m SONth-

 --'s,s4srssss' -Is Sr s'S's--& Noaia .os os .,.aa. Rna >Iu s.s-s-z'p. .- --rsnS - ,f rrc.dwelI nine would come first, the = hite Pass & Yukon Railway second and Mocre's Wharf third. The two latter are closely allied as the wharf is the tcrmi- nus Of the railroad. and goods can be taken from the vessel and placed in the ears on the other side Of the wharf. Very soon the railroad company will have in operation a large steam crane. and by the use of this it will be possible Co llft heavy freight from the steamers hold directly 0n Co the cars standing on the tracks. II s possible. also. that track will be laid along the sea front of the wharf Co further facilitate trans-shipment.

 The Moores Wharf Company has al- ways shown It's enterprise in planning for the future and making large outlays in ad- vance of present requirments. and time las proved the soundness of its Judgment. Last year the company spent about S0O.- iOO ln construction work alone. all In prep lratlon for the great travel we had through .his port last season. and in full conh- fence that there would be this large traf- ic. The company is sometimes unfavorabiy eferred to as a foreign corporation. Tor which there Is no basis except that some of It's shareholders reside In London; but t has certainly proven Itself Co be more American than most American Investors ln the abiding faith it has shown as to the certain growth and coming importance of Skagwsy.

 The company is now completing still further important Improvements. all un- dertaken in iu plicit confidence that the commerce cf this rort will this year fully warrant these large eXnendltur's. These improvements begin at tho wharf end or tho approach Of 2S00 feet. which Ia to bo made double its present width Co give mora accommodation for drays and hot'l ,mnlbuses. The wharf Itself has bccn eN- tended for the coming season, 80 that there will be a deep water froatase or yVo feet. which will give ample space for five large steamers 70 dock and unload at tho same timo. other facilities In keeping wi,l this increas1 of accommodation have been made. one Of which Is a new bonded ware house O. nearly the same dimensions. and there Is also. for local business. cold storage for meats and 30 forth. and warm storagc warehouse for vegctg6cs. fruits and perlshable goods generally. so tha, they may not be touched by the frost

 The company has had th, city water la,C ,n to the wharf, SO that steamers may take on their supply Of water while unloading Instead Of having t1 make special trip across the bay fos the purpose.

 All these great Improvements. too. arc but the beginning. it being the Intention of the company to continue Co keep itr wharf facilities ahead of the present needs of the business. What has s0 fas been completed has always been done on foro- ,ast of the needs for the following sc2- son Those male last winter. for Instance, were shown Co O. based on good Julgm nt 1f the amount o' traflc that would como this way. for in one single mOath Of last summer 5Oo0 tons O; freight were landed 1n its wharf |, Is these large returns u}- n the Investment that have encouraged the company Co again make lavish expendi- lure ln preparation for the rush by this

 .ut" .1 Nome.

 A frst-c!ass system O; handling 'fe!g1t

 cysils ig tie wharf management, and ustons onccrs are kept at the wharf to

 rovidc for the sreedy release and trans iAipmcnt of bonded goods. and also to supervise the shipments of American mer- chandlse.

 Everybody In Skagway takes a deep in- terest in the enterprise of the Moore's Wharf Company and also in the wharf Itself Tn the summer it Is the city's boule- yard and most fashionable promenade There they go to fish. or to join boating parties, or merely to enjoy the sea breeze and the sunshine and the reflection Of the snowclad peaks In the clear blue waters of the bay.

ttNttN-@ wv " " V " V " V | Three years ago one would never have Exposed that there would ever be any Connection between the supposed barren Inns and dales of Alaska and higher. or |,ny other kind of education, except in Iplsslonary way to the tribes Of Indians locatod here and there.

 Alaska Of today and then are two dif- terent countries. then bleak, barren. al- Host unknown; but now Uncle Sam's most Tpluahlc territory, and possessing as flour Nhing cities and towns as any other part f his domain. From transient mining .amps have sprung permanent cities with elegant homes. and every appliance that modern ingenuity could give has been utilized. With all this came the necessity for schools and to keep our boys and girls at home insrvad of sending them to the

 .outh became a vital Issue.

 iS' -'t t--it,s-lasv-tI. J. Walters, Ph. D., slons by the VI. E. Church. aEu- seelt. s~s-s needs of the people. he at once seized the opportunity. and together with few not able citlzens-Dr. I. II. Moore. Messrs. Whiting. Sengfelder. Burnham. Shorthill. Brownell, Dr.. Nlskern. Hayne and few others. a good subscription list was gotten up and the foundation stone of the first collegiate school In Alaska was laid by Di Kellogg of oregon. in the presence of

 Large concourse of people from all plfts.

 The founders. regularly organized as a

 )oard Of trustees. named the institution rMcCabe College" after Bishop c. c. Mc-

 ,abe. D. D.. who has done more for the Methodist Episcopal Church in Alaska than any other man. It being important that work should begin In the fall of '99. the board elected Rev pr. Lamont Gordon, A. M.. and B. Sc. of oxford University and Aberdeen. Scotland. as the first president. Dr. Gordon. who was president of the N. E. Seminary at Du Pont. Ca. was notl- fed. and. with his family. arrived in Skag- way on September lith. and on tho 18th

Moores Wharf Is often referred Co as ae of the greatest investments In south

are W. II. Blackwell. Thos. W. Farns- worth, the nrst Arctic Chief. Ernest F. Miller and hls brother. August II. Miller, Major Strickland. of the Northwest mount cd police, and c. 0. Rinearson. They wore the original suggestors Of the movement, and at the first meeting they added to their numbers Dr. A. II. Bryant. the real estate dealer: pr. Mahlon F. Hall, Charles E. Moody. sbanker; Ernest Peck, lawyer Harrie n. Thaeher. who was the hrst Camp Recorder; James A. Kettles. W. A. Miller and Captain E. w. Johnston. or these there are now resident In Skagway and as active members of the organization. as they were at its inception. the Miller Brothers. who were the first Arctic guides over the new ly blazed trail. W. II. Blackwell and James \. Kettles. the first Trail Blazer elected by the order. The credit for the title Of Arctic Brotherhood Is due to Major Striek- land. The Skagway Camp has long been a parent and Is really the Grand Camp or the order. although not yet formally or ganized as such. lt has already establish cd prosperous camps at Bennett, Tagish. Atlin. Dawson. Circle City and Juneau Of the membership Of these camps there Is no recent record at hand. but it can b. safely estimated that its rosters would place the total number of members of the order at from one thousand to fifteen hundred. And all this has been accom- plished since March last. The camps at Bennett, Tagish and Atlin were personally established by the first Arctic Chief. Thom- as W. Farnsworth.

 IIs MUSEUM FEATURES.

 The Brotherhood's building at this port is two stories high and measures thirty feet by ninety. Of this the lodge room takes up twenty-nine and a half feet by sixty. the full two stories in height. Then there Is the wide entrance hall and the spacious reception and reading room be- fore referred to, and three dressing rooms. Above these Is a wide balcony for the or chestra, composed of members, which dis courses sweet music throughout the work of the ritual and emphasizes its solemnlty or gives the signal for seemly mirth. A quartette of male voices also occupies the balcony during the lodge meetings. Back of this balcony and fronting on Broad way Ia A large room intended for billiards and a sleeping apartment Tor the mouse steward. The whole building is completely ! furnished in excellent taste. and Is just beg,nning to receive those interesting and home-like touches which could only have been given by personal gifts to it of Alaska relies, Indian curios. mineralogieal speel- mems. furs. art work iu gnarled branches of trees. pictures and books and SO on.

 This handsome club house has un- loubtedly been an important factor In the rapid growth of the order. Members trav- cling to the interior And in it home or comfort where they can spend their hours of waiting in reading. writing. playing games, greeting old acQuaintances anu forming new ones. It Is the place of all places. before its glowing open hfeplace. To sWap bad luck stories" Co recount the hardships gone through before the enjoy ment of such luxury was reached. On the visitors book of the club there are all ready many pages of names. and the writ CTS og every one Of these autographs VIII heartily join with the Daily Alaskan In

 wis ing the Brotherhood "A Happy New Year"

opened up the college In temporary quar- ters at the corner of Eighth and Main Streets. Now some fifty students are ad- yanclng rapidly and under as good chances as they could in any school in the United States.

 Mrs. E. s. V. McComb, the preceptress of the primary department, is an accom- pllshed lady. and Is graduate of Miehi- gan University.

 Mrs. l.. Gordon. wife of the president, has also begun a Kindergarten class in con nectlon with the collegiate school. Mrs. Gordon graduated at Piedmont College, Cumming. Ca. the first school In the United States that Dr. Gordon presided over.

 Parents now have no excuse 10 send their children below. Higher education has got It's start in Alaska and the magnificent na- tive granite building now nearly com pleted will be the pride of Skagway and Alaska. IL will lead to other high schools at Juneau. Dawson and other points. anu skagway College will be the graduating centre.

full articles.headline: FURNITURE MAKER.
full articles.article:
During the first year of skagway's his- tory nearly every man who remained the major portion of that time had reaped a success at least sufficiently large to justi- fy him In sending for his family and mak- Ing this his permanent home. Homes in- numerable sprung up everywhere, in the busy city and in It's quiet suburbs. and builders, carpenters, house painters and paper hangers were soon reaplng a rich harvest. But they are not sufficient in themselves to make home. After the house Is completed it needs furniture to make it a home. And SO great was the de- mand for furniture that E. k. Peoples felt Justified in starting a manufactory to meet lt. That his venture has proven a success Is substantially shown by the fact that his business buildings now occupy such a large piece of ground and that he Is again considering the adyisabllty of enlarging

 The salesrooms and sample rooms are 5Ox5O feet, and the manufacturing depart ment occupies two floors of a building ad- joining of 75x25 feet. In this latter de- partment ten workmer are employed. who turn out all kinds Of upholstery and wood work. from the latef styles of drawing room luxury to the md'o necessary kitchen | table What should make Skagway proud Of | this establishment is not the fact that | lt has added another dnner bucket brigade | to her labor army 80 rpich as that lt Is the | arst Alaskan enterprA to engage in the

 manufacture Of one oiher greates. prod

 Iets,, that of her fofsts The timber wealth of the district 50 immehsc as to

 be entirely beyond c1;ulation. and Con

 gross a long time agopassed resolution

 that none of this timbr should be export.

 cd cut of Alaska. IL sbuld have added an

 other section to this slct giving bonus

 10 those who manufltured the product

 and 80 protect those Tho engaged in this

 new enterprise In thisew country against ,he competition of thduge concerns In the States whose machinl flood the market with the cheap furnitlb that makes homes tawdry.

 Mir. Peoples did notTalt for this protcc- tion-probably never bought Of it-anl certainly has no needo fear such compe- titlon. For folding bet bookcases, tables, chairs and so on, oithe less expensive kind. he Is now uslniAlaska spruce. He finds some of 1t of a Iperior quality, and with good workmen tns out an excellent

 article that Is a cred to the first home

 manufacture Of this mense home prod

 uct.

 When the dlscussldof Alaskan affairs comes up before Congss this session, and some one asks: WI are we going to do with our vast veal of Alaska timber; how are we to get arhing out of 1t un- less permission Is graRd to ship 1t out Of

 Alaska?" the answerllll be: Ask Peo-

 ples. of Skagway."

SKAGWAY WOMEN.
full articles.article:
W " W V V V @ NE of the mos, Ha,tering incidents " of the reception given to the Amer iean members of the Joint High Com mission and United States Senators last summer. m the large pavilion erected by the Chamber of Commerce for the. fur- pose, Va. their expressions of surprise at the fashionable evening toilettes of the Sksgway women present. What is more pleasing is the fact that the com bhmeut came from women of the leading society of the United States, the wives and friends of the distinguished visitors. For il Is true that man Is an unreliable critic in such m tters, and although the softer sex dress and array themselves in all the modest pride that Art invents her beauty to improve" for the express purpose of pleasing aud attracting the sterne, sex, yet the latter sees only the general effects, and never troubles him- self as to how they are produced.

 The compliment was ss well-deserved as il was Asttering. With the prosperity of the first wiuler m mind, the meu who had Toughed il iu bachelor dirt and dis order sent for their wives and families; homes were built for them and other families followed. Prosperity eontinu- iug, the wives and grown daughters be- gan to wear it's outward ant visible signs. Where "any old thing" seemed to be good enough in the beginning tue femi- mine mind began to ponder upon and desire the latest fashionable fads and faueies. Then came, according to the natural laws of supply and demand, the firm of ]. $. Graham, which started hist on Fourth avenue but some time later had to seek larger quarters and IS now well-established in the Kelly block. This hrm Is the only one in the city that devotes itself entirely 10 what is called "ladies' furnishings" but it also carries a large stock, constantly renewed, Of tue latest fashions in cloaks aud taller made suits and hats. That our women appre ciatr this and are able to keep themselves well in tue van of fashions rapid march, is shown by the fact that Chicago poet some months ago tuned his Tyre to tue tune of "rhe Grey Goose Qniil." The ladies of Skagway had been wearing the grey goose quill iu their hats for weeks before that poem appeared.

When the wearled Yukoner comes In on 1s evening train. the first thing to strike hls eye is the warm glow from tho win sows of the Arctic Brotherhood Cub. just across the way from the depot. lt looks to him. especially n he Is member of the brotnsrnood. like comfort. civilization. home. full articles.headline: co TO sEATTLBY EXPRESS.
full articles.article: When the steamefCity of Seattle" started on her fast ts from this port direct to the Sound, le boat found no favor with the hotel bprietors. in fact. they complained that } took away their guests too quickly. Bubw they look upon the fleet steamer. altlgh she only stays a few hours in port. a sort of public benefactor. for she made such a rep- utation for comfort aiqulck passage that people from the inter will wait here for "City of Seattle" h In fact, won the first place in steam9opularity. and her passenger list on dy trip down must have made glad thaarts of her Seattle owners. In one mot of the past season she carried from hdbOO passengers. Her record trip from h to Seattle was 70 hours and her rect for the round trip six days and threehrs.

The corner bakery and eating house be- came n restaurant of the premier class with plate glass windows and Interior ht- tings and decorations such as are only met win in the Delmonicos of the larger cities But he had scarcely made his new restaur- an, and bakery the full one hundred feet. Inc depth of his lot. than other parties sought to lease 1t. and a price was offered mat no business man in Skagway could have refused Then Mir. Ronkendorf built himself another large restaurant, In many was superior and more stylish than his first endeavor. This is on Sixth Avenue al- so. and 1t Is in every way credit 10 the cItv It is stlll called by It's old name, the German Bakery. for there is a bakery ad- iunct where anything from maccaroon to s bride cake can be made at short order. and as a caterer Mir. Ronkendorf Is equal to anything from q cold lunch to a sena- torlal banquet

full articles.headline: ls -sish, ye, harmonious eOiOrys.
full articles.article:
> Is -sight yet harmonious eOlOrfg v

 he Brothernood has grown evef niore than SAagway itself lt only started last spring. with about a dozen charter mem brrs, yet lts roster today carries near,y 5v0 members with a number Of limitations at every weekly meeting; therefore it ia bound to be tle most powerful organiza- ,.ou ln Alaska. It's membership includes lau Governor and the Judge of the United States ulsulct Court and other Alaskan o..elaIs. omcers of the United states army ant navy. many of the best known klon- diaers. the leading lawyers. doctors anu u., rc.lu.s Og sSagway. majors. inspectors auI trIyatys of the Canadian police ana .taer British born. For the order Is en- t...ly uou- political. and whatever the A--er.cau or the Canadian may individ- u-4y ,ninA of tle Alasaa boundary Ques t.a. ae cannot faIl Co notice tn the lodge .oo.- ,ac Stars aud St.ipes and the Union Ja-A .utN.ned. With the motto connect i-s tAem. No Boundary Llno Here"

 BEACY OF Is RITUAL.

 Nc, oa.y ln mere membership has the or Ear.z-..-I SO rapidly grown. but tho char a.--r of Q. lIs gradually changed as mort men ot s.gl attlinments joined and tooA an .r-,r.s. .a its work. It was. for In stance. w. e1 ssA. ted. ittle. anything. a ore -aa. cu association for mere amuse u-Ls. >g.a then. however. men of taclg lt'ui minds have been more promi- utlt iu .ts cllnssls. men too. who wore hiya up .a ots1s secret orde.s. and under the summation of this Influence the ritual has sroVa fr,n its somewhat uncertain carys1lis Co one as beautiful in lts teach ings ss the work of any secret order. with DO Wor-s ss!d or things done In "a inltl- Ua.ory cerrmon.-s that are without their NeigAt Of thoaght'ul significance. It was that characteristic that led a gentleman Go refua.k after his initiation "I Ike thii bolt than any of the orders Co whlch beloLg. lt is so thoroughly Alaskan la all its work ani lu all its teachings. and therefore Of such service and bereat to those of tho country of whose manhood it Ia 10 stiiking an example"

 The order was fortunate In lts second selection ot an Arctic Chiet Co have in Major J. T. Hayue one who was not only an Ideal presiding officer.- but one who had held high positions in the Knights ot Pyth- iaA At the election Of officers last Soyem Der. the Brotherhood was equally fortu- nate iu les choice. Dr. [. II. Moore being q most enthusiastic Mason. He has been earnest In carrying on the work Of Major Haync. and In his devotion to the perfsc- tion of the ritual and the improvement oi the order Co point tn keeping with it' prospective greatness.

 But this must not be taken literally as meaning that with the advent of Major Hayne as Arctic Chief the reformation Of the ritual begun. It was tn evidence at every session Of the Brotherhood from its nrst. and thls gradual but continual deyel- opment of a central Idea is but another demonstration Of the high mental calibre s.N Hh hs. hR In kl n it tuolr home and to build up their for tunes On an average. perhaps. ten have been Initiated st each weekly scssion. anu Of them there was one or more who saw clearly the great future which tho orier might develop Into under proper ggldanee, ana they came Co the fore with suggestions born Of their cosmopolitan experience and their mental capacity.

 THOSE WHO BLAZED THE TRAIL.

 It would not be proper and. Ia fact. it would be invidlous to mention any of these unless one could mention all. and to mention ail Is impossible. for the req son that many of them believe their ef- foI ts for the good of the order. like the charity it dispenses. should be a sacred matter of personal satisfaction. of which publicity would brush the dew of modest graciousness and brotherly generosity.

 But it Is fitting In an article of thlS kind. a brief history of powerful organI- ration which came Into existence humbly and has fought it way up to It's present high position since the Issue of our last New Years edition. that some honor should be paid 10 its founders. tho men who blazed the trail. and. In great measure. spent their own time and money in doing lt.

 To be registered As thess trail blaEors

full articles.headline:
THE GERMAN BAKERY AND ITS

 PROPRIETOR.
full articles.article:
One of the first of the better class Of restaurants established in the now city Of skagway was that of Fred Ronkendori. who came here with not only lot Of cx- perienee but some hard cash In addition to go Into business. Of an energetic and genial temperament that readily makes Of business aeQuaintances personal friends

 and with full knowledge of what he was attempting and how to go about 1t. a man in any line of business could hardly fall of success. especially In new country. Mir. Ronkendorf aid not fail by any means. His German Bakery was very soon a pop ular eating house and as the city grew and put on trills. so did Fred's establishment.

ue Of the greatest luNestments m SONth-

 --'s,s4srssss' -Is Sr s'S's--& Noaia .os os .,.aa. Rna >Iu s.s-s-z'p. .- --rsnS - ,f rrc.dwelI nine would come first, the = hite Pass & Yukon Railway second and Mocre's Wharf third. The two latter are closely allied as the wharf is the tcrmi- nus Of the railroad. and goods can be taken from the vessel and placed in the ears on the other side Of the wharf. Very soon the railroad company will have in operation a large steam crane. and by the use of this it will be possible Co llft heavy freight from the steamers hold directly 0n Co the cars standing on the tracks. II s possible. also. that track will be laid along the sea front of the wharf Co further facilitate trans-shipment.

 The Moores Wharf Company has al- ways shown It's enterprise in planning for the future and making large outlays in ad- vance of present requirments. and time las proved the soundness of its Judgment. Last year the company spent about S0O.- iOO ln construction work alone. all In prep lratlon for the great travel we had through .his port last season. and in full conh- fence that there would be this large traf- ic. The company is sometimes unfavorabiy eferred to as a foreign corporation. Tor which there Is no basis except that some of It's shareholders reside In London; but t has certainly proven Itself Co be more American than most American Investors ln the abiding faith it has shown as to the certain growth and coming importance of Skagwsy.

 The company is now completing still further important Improvements. all un- dertaken in iu plicit confidence that the commerce cf this rort will this year fully warrant these large eXnendltur's. These improvements begin at tho wharf end or tho approach Of 2S00 feet. which Ia to bo made double its present width Co give mora accommodation for drays and hot'l ,mnlbuses. The wharf Itself has bccn eN- tended for the coming season, 80 that there will be a deep water froatase or yVo feet. which will give ample space for five large steamers 70 dock and unload at tho same timo. other facilities In keeping wi,l this increas1 of accommodation have been made. one Of which Is a new bonded ware house O. nearly the same dimensions. and there Is also. for local business. cold storage for meats and 30 forth. and warm storagc warehouse for vegctg6cs. fruits and perlshable goods generally. so tha, they may not be touched by the frost

 The company has had th, city water la,C ,n to the wharf, SO that steamers may take on their supply Of water while unloading Instead Of having t1 make special trip across the bay fos the purpose.

 All these great Improvements. too. arc but the beginning. it being the Intention of the company to continue Co keep itr wharf facilities ahead of the present needs of the business. What has s0 fas been completed has always been done on foro- ,ast of the needs for the following sc2- son Those male last winter. for Instance, were shown Co O. based on good Julgm nt 1f the amount o' traflc that would como this way. for in one single mOath Of last summer 5Oo0 tons O; freight were landed 1n its wharf |, Is these large returns u}- n the Investment that have encouraged the company Co again make lavish expendi- lure ln preparation for the rush by this

 .ut" .1 Nome.

 A frst-c!ass system O; handling 'fe!g1t

 cysils ig tie wharf management, and ustons onccrs are kept at the wharf to

 rovidc for the sreedy release and trans iAipmcnt of bonded goods. and also to supervise the shipments of American mer- chandlse.

 Everybody In Skagway takes a deep in- terest in the enterprise of the Moore's Wharf Company and also in the wharf Itself Tn the summer it Is the city's boule- yard and most fashionable promenade There they go to fish. or to join boating parties, or merely to enjoy the sea breeze and the sunshine and the reflection Of the snowclad peaks In the clear blue waters of the bay.

full articles.headline:
,s..,.s.eoa,eee9.ga99a:.p :.pa@e

HIGHER EDUCATION.
full articles.article:
ttNttN-@ wv " " V " V " V | Three years ago one would never have Exposed that there would ever be any Connection between the supposed barren Inns and dales of Alaska and higher. or |,ny other kind of education, except in Iplsslonary way to the tribes Of Indians locatod here and there.

 Alaska Of today and then are two dif- terent countries. then bleak, barren. al- Host unknown; but now Uncle Sam's most Tpluahlc territory, and possessing as flour Nhing cities and towns as any other part f his domain. From transient mining .amps have sprung permanent cities with elegant homes. and every appliance that modern ingenuity could give has been utilized. With all this came the necessity for schools and to keep our boys and girls at home insrvad of sending them to the

 .outh became a vital Issue.

 iS' -'t t--it,s-lasv-tI. J. Walters, Ph. D., slons by the VI. E. Church. aEu- seelt. s~s-s needs of the people. he at once seized the opportunity. and together with few not able citlzens-Dr. I. II. Moore. Messrs. Whiting. Sengfelder. Burnham. Shorthill. Brownell, Dr.. Nlskern. Hayne and few others. a good subscription list was gotten up and the foundation stone of the first collegiate school In Alaska was laid by Di Kellogg of oregon. in the presence of

 Large concourse of people from all plfts.

 The founders. regularly organized as a

 )oard Of trustees. named the institution rMcCabe College" after Bishop c. c. Mc-

 ,abe. D. D.. who has done more for the Methodist Episcopal Church in Alaska than any other man. It being important that work should begin In the fall of '99. the board elected Rev pr. Lamont Gordon, A. M.. and B. Sc. of oxford University and Aberdeen. Scotland. as the first president. Dr. Gordon. who was president of the N. E. Seminary at Du Pont. Ca. was notl- fed. and. with his family. arrived in Skag- way on September lith. and on tho 18th

full articles.article:
1TTnHE name of Kaufman Bros. is as .

 "household word" in Alaska, thl brothers having cone from Olympia ant established themselves m Juneau year and years ago. There their store is feature of the principal street aud IS th' lvadiug store iu its liue m tue city. TiI bio.nets have done much the same thii heie. Very early iu 1893, iu fact as sos as tue town showed any reliable signs

 permauency, ;. C. aud l. K.uluau Csa

 t-town aud secured prem'ses m

 Aas tlsa the only business blog

 .Iosdwsy,...-.-..s,ul,s.--..-...s,r.., .s,r .., goods. and particularly to all the dGiae fabrics with winch woman IS wont l. adorn herself, the Kaufman bro,hen soon built up large t.ade. Their prem ises were too small. They enlarged them They were siill too small, and they pur- chased piece of property on Fifth ave uue on which 10 build the largest J;ore of it's kind in Alaska. But there was some trouble about fraction Of the property purchased, or which they intended 10 purchase, and building operations have not yet been begun. Both brothers are members of the ChambeT cf Commerce, aud Mir. I. Kaufman |, also an energetic member oi Hook and Ladder Co. No [.
